results.title: Desperate living (E)
results.brief_description: Only John Water’s could conjure up a fairytale which featured amongst other things, cannibalism, rabies, castration and general debauchery. Peggy Gravel (Waters’ regular Mink Stole), a respected but slightly unhinged Baltimore citizen finds herself on the run with her obese, black maid, Grizelda (Jean Hill), when they accidentally murder Peggy’s husband. The two outlaws eventually end up in Mortville, a lawless shanty town populated by deviant criminals and ruled over by the evil Queen Carlotta (Edith Massey) and her leather clad biker troops. What follows is classic Waters, as Peggy and Grizelda have to contend with perverted cops, lecherous lesbians, an outbreak of rabies, and a demented queens unreasonable whims. Working for the first time without his regular leading lady, Divine, Waters hands the reigns over to Edith Massey (the crib bound egg lady from Waters infamous “Pink Flamingo’s”), an appropriate substitute to fill the famous drag queen’s pumps, and if one star wasn’t enough, busty strip artiste Liz Renay makes a wonderfully sleazy film debut as Muffy St. Jacques, a part originally intended for Divine (who was touring in her one woman show at the time). All the while Waters tries his best to gross us out and make us laugh. Long live the Pope of trash! Cast includes Susan Lowe and Mary Vivian Pearce. See also “Serial Mom”, “Hairspray”, “Cry baby”, “Polyester”.

results.title: The Storm riders = Fung Wan: Hungba Tinha
results.creator_credit: Andrew Lau, Manfred Wong, Li Zhu An, Centro Digital and Golden Harvest
results.brief_description: A martial arts fantasy film adapted from the long-running manga comic. The Lord Conqueror orphans two children, Wind and Cloud, then brings them up as his disciples. Ten years later the two are set against each other as they rival for the affections of Charity, the Lord Conqueror’s daughter. In Cantonese with English subtitles. Cast includes: Aaron Kwok, Ekin Cheng, Sonny Chiba, Kristy Yang and Shu Oi.

results.title: My darling Clementine
results.creator_credit: John Ford, Samuel G. Engel and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Considered one of the greatest westerns of all time, this is also Ford’s most consciously poetic western heavily overlaid with the weight of myth: the pitting of dark against light, wilderness against garden, paradise lost and then regained. A revenge plot culminating in the gunfight at the OK Corral is set against the leisurely and romantic portrayal of a period epitomised by the ritual celebration of community in the square dance. Henry Fonda plays Wyatt Earp, the wanderer planning to settle, the mover between worlds. The foil to Earp is the tragic figure of Doc Holliday (Victor Mature). Based on a book by Stuart N. Lake from a story by Sam Hellman. Cast also includes Linda Darnell.

results.title: Mandragora [Widescreen] (E)
results.creator_credit: Wiktor Grodecki, Miroslav Steinbach, Petr Heinvosky, Jaraslav Stanek and Prague Film Enterprises
results.brief_description: The director of this film has worked most of the 1990s with the young prostitutes and homeless in Prague, making a series of documentaries examining the development of the sex trade industry in the Czech Republic. The feature length film uses the conventions of melodrama and neo-realism (non-professional actors, real locations) in order to make a powerful statement against the corruption and exploitation of young people in market-obsessed post-Communist Prague. Sixteen year old Mark arrives in Prague after running away from his country town and within hours has begun life as a street prostitute. The film represents a dark labyrinth world where adults prey on children and where the only moments of tenderness rest in the relationships formed between the young boys. But in a world of random violence and theft, of corrupt pornographers and pimps, of desperate drug use and sexual disease, and in a world where the foreign tourist is most often a pedophile, moments of tenderness are few and far between. In Czech with English subtitles.

results.title: Le Souffle au coeur = Dearest love = Murmur of the Heart
results.creator_credit: Louis Malle, Claude Nedjar, Vincent Malle, Vides Film, NEF Filmproduktion, Marianne Productions and Franz Seitz Filmproduktion
results.brief_description: Laurent (Benoit Ferreux) is the fourteen year old youngest son of a rich bourgeois provincial doctor (Daniel Gelin). It is 1954, the French are still involved in Vietnam, the hardships of the war years are in the past, and for Laurent, who is endlessly pampered by his adoring mother (Lea Massari) and two oldest brothers, life is very sweet indeed. Louis Malle’s “Le Souffle au Coeur” is a surprisingly acerbic comedy about the privileges and causal amoralities of the middle class. The surprise is in how tender Malle is towards the sexual and physical experiences of adolescence. Masturbation, virginity, initiation to prostitution, incestuous feelings; all are treated with a gentle mockery that strips them of fetishism or gross perversity. In fact, it is selfishness of wealth that is the real perversity in this intoxicating film. When young Laurent finally gives expression to his sexual desire for his beautiful girlish mother, we are treated to one of the few moments in cinema history where incest is treated not with terror or with guilt but as part of the animal instincts of the human animal. Undoubtedly, Malle’s intention was to focus on the social and economic conditions that gave rise to the massive bourgeois protests of the late 1960s, however he refuses to make his wicked family monstrous or to scapegoat them entirely for the faults of their class. Laurent, his brothers and his parents are oblivious to any of the darkness that exists in the world around them. “Le Souffle au Coeur” which could be subtitled “Memoirs of a Catholic Childhood” is one of the most refreshingly secular films ever made. (PLEASE NOTE: THIS ENGLISH SUBTITLED PRINT HAS BEEN SLIGHTLY CENSORED BECAUSE OF THE CONTROVERSIAL NATURE OF THE MATERIAL). In French with English subtitles. NATURE OF )

results.title: Tristana [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Luis Bunuel, Talia Films, Les Films Corona, Epoca Films and Selina Cinematografia
results.brief_description: Fernando Rey plays Don Lope, a free thinking, Spanish dandy who’s liberal ideals are tested when he is entrusted with the guardianship of the beautiful and innocent Tristana (Catherine Deneuve). Soon enough, fatherly affection develops into full blown lust and obsession, as Don Lope coerces Tristana into becoming his lover, all the while maintaining she is free to see other men. However, Don Lope’s principals begin to fall apart when Tristana meets and falls in love with a handsome young artist (Franco Nero), sending the aging lothario into a jealous rage. Tristana is one of director Luis Bunuel’s more sombre efforts, but underlining this tragic tale of the corruption and abuse of power is his trade mark savage wit, his taste for sexual perversity (at one point a prosthetic leg is imbued with a strange erotic tension), and his contempt for the hypocrisy of the church and the ruling class. Adapted from a novel by Benito Perez Galdos. Cast includes Lola Gaos and Jesus Fernandez. In Spanish with English subtitles.

results.title: Mrs Brown = Her Majesty Mrs Brown (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: John Madden, Sarah Curtis, Ecosse Films, Mobil Masterpiece Theatre, WGBH (Boston) and BBC
results.brief_description: Set at the height of Victorian England, ‘Mrs Brown’ tells of the extraordinary relationship between a Queen and a commoner. Judi Dench gives a stunning performance (which was reflected by her Best Actress nomination), as Queen Victoria who begins a doomed, and ultimately tragic relationship with her servant, John Brown (Billy Connolly). Brown brings comfort and life to the Queen’s long period of mourning following the death of her husband, Albert. Where others failed to cheer her up, Brown succeeds, and in doing so secures the Queen’s respect and friendship. The Victorian court is suspicious of their leader’s new found happiness which forces the Queen and Brown to make some painful choices about their relationship, their own needs, and the monarchy. Cast includes Antony Sher, Geoffrey Palmer, Richard Pasco and David Westhead.

results.title: Mon homme
results.creator_credit: Bertrand Blier, Alain Sarde, Canal+, Studio Images 2, Plateau A and Les Films Alain Sarde
results.brief_description: This darkly humorous, erotic drama centres on Marie, an independent prostitute with a heart of gold. After rescuing a down-and-out homeless man one night, she falls in love with him and invites him to be her pimp. Soon he starts recruiting other women - the inexperience of one of the new recruits landing them all in jail. Discovering her lover’s duplicity, Marie decides to reform. In French with English subtitles. Cast includes Anouk Grinberg, Gerard Lanvin, Valeria Bruni-Tedeschi and Olivier Martinez. Winner of the Silver Bear Best Actress award at the Berlin Film Festival 1996.

results.title: Get out your handkerchiefs = Preparez vos mouchoirs
results.creator_credit: Bertrand Blier, Paul Claudon, Alexande Minouchkine, George Dancigers and Interama
results.brief_description: Gerard Depardieu is Raoul, a young working-class man devoted to his wife, Solange, played by Carole Laure. Convinced that Solange has tired of him, he convinces a stranger, Stephan (Patrick Dewaere), to enter a menage-a-trois with himself and Solange. However, no matter how hard they try, no matter how much love they offer Solange, they are unable to bring a smile to her face or make her fall pregnant (which they believe is all that she really needs). A trip away to a summer camp leads to Solange meeting the precocious Christian, a thirteen year old boy with the IQ of a genius. At first, she attempts to mother the boy, but finds herself slowly seduced by him, and Stephan and Raoul can only stand-by and watch as the teenager gives Solange everything they cannot. This wickedly sly comedy about marriage, sexual mores, and the differences between men and women won the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language film in 1978. Though definitely absurdist in its sensibility, “Get Out Your Handkerchiefs” refuses to treat its characters cynically or cruelly. Rather, it is as if in examining the fall-out of the sexual revolution, Blier’s response is to throw up his arms, laugh at the madness of it all, and finally to celebrate the madness of the battle of the sexes. In French with English subtitles.

This wickedly sly comedy about marriage, sexual mores, and the differences between men and women won the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language film in 1978. Though definitely absurdist in its sensibility, “Get Out Your Handkerchiefs” refuses to treat its characters cynically or cruelly. Rather, it is as if in examining the fall-out of the sexual revolution, Blier’s response is to throw up his arms, laugh at the madness of it all, and finally to celebrate the madness of the battle of the sexes. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Lacombe Lucien [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Louis Malle, Hallelujuh, VIDES Cinematografica, Universal Pictures France and Nouvelles Éditions de Films
results.brief_description: Lucien Lacombe (Pierre Blaise) is a young peasant trying to make ends meet in Nazi-occupied France. Bored with his job cleaning in a country hospital, he first tries joining the Resistance, then the Gestapo, in his search for excitement and to earn some extra cash. He puts his own success as a collaborator at risk, however, when he finds himself falling in love with, and then exploiting, the daughter of a Jewish tailor (Aurore Clement). Using an almost detached camera, Louis Malle’s controversial film is a verite-style drama of corruption, apathy and amorality. Young Lucien’s succumbing to the allure and promises of the Nazis’ is not an isolated act but a response to the casual war profiteering, prostitution and opportunism that he sees the adults around him engaging in. What is truly shocking is the ease with which people are shown becoming accustomed to the most vile and extreme acts of torture and genocide. Malle’s discreet and circumspect mise-en-scene resists manipulating the viewer through sensationalism or moral self-righteousness; Lucien’s descent is all too identifiably human. On it’s release “Lacombe Lucien” was widely acclaimed as one of the director’s greatest films, but it was also savagely maligned as a betrayal of the heroism of the French people, and a betrayal of the promise and hopes of the Resistance (a criticism echoed by both left and right). In the end, “Lacombe Lucien” is one of the few films that can be argued to not only de-romanticise our most popular conceptions of war, but also manages to deal effectively, bravely and unforgettably, with the “banality of Evil”. In French with English subtitles.
